channel.title: Read Rust - All Posts
channel.description: All Posts posts on Read Rust

item.title: A Case Study in Heaptrack
item.description:
When I first started building the dtparse crate, my intention was to mirror as closely as possible the equivalent Python library. Python, as you may know, is garbage collected. Very rarely is memory usage considered in Python, and I likewise wasn‚Äôt paying too much attention when dtparse was first being built.
This lackadaisical approach to memory works well enough, and I‚Äôm not planning on making dtparse hyper-efficient. But every so often, I‚Äôve wondered: ‚Äúwhat exactly is going on in memory?‚Äù
item.dc:creator: Bradlee Speice

item.title: Declarative Rust static analysis
item.description: Rust's Macros 2.0 are intuitive: demonstrate a pattern, and the compiler can insert the pattern into your program wherever you want it. Inspired by this syntax, I wondered: Could you ‚Äúrun a macro backwards‚Äù‚Äîuse the same by-example language to describe patterns to search for?
item.dc:creator: Kaz Wesley

item.title: Testing reqwest-based clients
item.description: In this article we will make a small Rust library that uses the reqwest http client library, and see what we can do to adequately test the business logic. We assume you have the Rust toolchain installed, and are at least passingly familiar with programming in Rust.
item.dc:creator: balrogboogie

item.title: GLSL quasiquoting in Rust!
item.description: glsl-quasiquote-0.1 was released today! The crate provides you with two macros: glsl! and glsl_str!. Both are procedural macros that requires a nightly compiler and the proc_macro_non_items feature. They will both output a TranslationUnit, that represents a whole shader AST.
item.dc:creator: Dimitri Sabadie

item.title: Default values¬†..copy that
item.description: When I talk to folks foreign to Rust, I often get asked the question: ‚ÄúWhy doesn‚Äôt Rust have support for default arguments‚Äù. When I first started learning Rust I pondered the same question. Eventually I came to realize that it does, kind of. Rust just takes different approach based on it‚Äôs unique design choices, one which I now wish other languages supported.
item.dc:creator: Doug Tangren

item.title: The Undergarden, a text adventure in Rust: 2 - Objects
item.description: In this second blog post I‚Äôm showing how I implemented objects - things the player can interact with - for a text adventure written in Rust. As usual, the full code is available on GitHub.
item.dc:creator: Michele Beltrame

item.title: WebAssembly and Dynamic Memory
item.description:
WebAssembly is a binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine. Wasm is designed as a portable target for compilation of high-level languages like C/C++/Rust, enabling deployment on the web for client and server applications.
These high-level languages like C/C++/Rust (+Javascript) deal with different allocations of memory, such as static memory, stack memory and dynamic memory.
item.dc:creator: Frank Rehberger

item.title: No, pest is not faster than nom
item.description: But today (October 4th, 2018), the pest website featured a very misleading graph. Yes, a pest 2.0 parser that does not convert the input to Rust types is indeed faster than a nom 4.0 parser that does convert the input to Rust types. But what happens if I write a nom 4.0 parser that does not convert its input to Rust types?
item.dc:creator: Geoffroy Couprie

item.title: Who authors the most popular crates on crates.io?
item.description: I had a question this morning: who authors the most popular crates on crates.io? First, we have to figure out what we mean by ‚Äúmost popular.‚Äù My first guess was ‚Äútop 100 by recent downloads‚Äù, so I looked at crates.io. Once I got to 100, I found... | Steve Klabnik | ‚ÄúThe most violent element in society is ignorance.‚Äù - Emma Goldman
item.dc:creator: Steve Klabnik

item.title: pest Parser 2.0 Released
item.description: pest is a general purpose parser written in Rust with a focus on accessibility, correctness, and performance. It uses parsing expression grammars (or PEG) as input, which are similar in spirit to regular expressions, but which offer the enhanced expressivity needed to parse complex languages.
item.dc:creator: Drago»ô Tiselice

item.title: Announcing the Tokio Doc Push (we need you!)
item.description:
In the past, there has been reoccurring feedback that Tokio is hard to understand. I believe a lack of good documentation plays a significant part. It‚Äôs time to fix this problem.
And because Tokio is open source, it is on us (the community) to make this happen! üëè
item.dc:creator: Carl Lerche

item.title: Introducing Ruukh Framework
item.description: Rust has its goals set on to be a primary WASM language and it would be awesome to use it both in backend and frontend web. Ruukh is one of such efforts to realise that dream. Ruukh, a frontend web framework, is inspired by both VueJS and ReactJS.
item.dc:creator: Sharad Chand

item.title: Lessons learned on writing web applications completely in Rust
item.description: This blog post is an update to the preceeding article ‚ÄúA web application completely written in Rust‚Äù and summarizes the projects‚Äô progress over the last months.
item.dc:creator: Sascha Grunert

item.title: Going Four Times Faster using Multi-Threading
item.description: Rust makes writing parallel code safe. Rayon makes it easy.
item.dc:creator: Justin Worthe

item.title: Red Hat's Stratis Storage Project Reaches Its 1.0 Stable Milestone
item.description: Stratis 1.0 was quietly released last week with the 1.0 version marking its initial stable release and where also the on-disk meta-data format has been stabilized. Red Hat engineers believe Stratis is now ready for more widespread testing.
item.dc:creator: Michael Larabel

item.title: Porting My CUDA Path Tracer to ptx-builder/linker
item.description: A bunch of stuff has happened since I published my post on The State of GPGPU in Rust. Most importantly, Denys Zariaiev (@denzp) released his work on a custom linker for Rust CUDA kernels, and a build.rs helper crate to make it easier to use. These two crates eliminate many of the problems I referred to in my previous post. The linker solves most of the ‚Äúinvalid PTX file‚Äù problems, while the ptx-builder crate does all of the magic that Accel was doing behind the scenes.
item.dc:creator: Brook Heisler

item.title: An EFI App a bit rusty
item.description: After two tweets that I made last week, playing around with UEFI and Rust, some people asked to publish a blog post explaining how to create a UEFI application fully written in Rust and demonstrate all the testing environment.
item.dc:creator: Gil Mendes

item.title: Understanding Compilers ‚Äî For Humans (Version 2)
item.description:
Understanding your compiler internally allows you to use it effectively. Walk through how programming languages and compilers work in this chronological synopsis. Lots of links, example code, and diagrams have been composed to aid in your understanding.
Understanding Compilers‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäFor Humans (Version 2) is a successor to my second article on Medium, with over 21 thousand views. I am so glad I could make a positive impact on people‚Äôs education, and I am excited to bring a complete rewrite based on the input I received from the original article. I chose Rust as this work‚Äôs primary language.
item.dc:creator: Luke Wilson

item.title: The relative performance of C and Rust
item.description:
I reimplemented a body of C software in Rust, and it performed better for the same task; what‚Äôs going on? And is there anything broader we can say about these results?
To explore this, I ran some statemap rendering tests on SmartOS on a single-socket Haswell server (Xeon E3-1270 v3) running at 3.50GHz. The C version was compiled with GCC 7.3.0 with -O2 level optimizations; the Rust version was compiled with 1.29.0 with --release. All of the tests were run bound to a processor set containing a single core; all were bound to one logical CPU within that core, with the other logical CPU forced to be idle. cpustat was used to gather CPU performance counter data, with one number denoting one run with pic0 programmed to that CPU performance counter. The input file (~30MB compressed) contains 3.5M state changes, and in the default config will generate a ~6MB SVG.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Cantrill

item.title: lolbench: automagically and empirically discovering Rust performance regressions
item.description: lolbench compiles ~350 benchmarks with every Rust nightly. It then runs them and highlights potential performance regressions in the standard library and the output of the compiler. Each toolchain‚Äôs run is summarized with a list of likely candidates, as seen in the image below, and we‚Äôre now getting started using these to safeguard the performance of Rust programs. Come help!
item.dc:creator: Adam Perry

item.title: Merlin: flexible, composable transcripts for zero-knowledge proofs
item.description: Merlin is a small Rust library that performs the Fiat-Shamir transformation in software, maintaining a STROBE-based transcript of the proof protocol and allowing the prover to commit messages to the transcript and compute challenges bound to all previous messages. It also provides a transcript-based RNG for use by the prover, generalizing ‚Äúdeterministic‚Äù and ‚Äúsynthetic‚Äù nonces to arbitrarily complex zero-knowledge protocols.
item.dc:creator: Henry de Valence

item.title: Tower Web 0.3 ‚Äî async/await and template support
item.description: Today, Tower Web 0.3 has been released and it comes with two major new features: Experimental support for async/await. Support for using templates to render responses.
item.dc:creator: Carl Lerche

item.title: Rust RPG: Introductory Tutorial of Rust, Unit Testing, and Continuous Integration with a Roguelike
item.description: We‚Äôre going to walk through a Rust application that I‚Äôve built, which is essentially a basic Roguelike in most regards.
item.dc:creator: Cameron Manavian

item.title: Programming WebAssembly with Rust ‚Äî The Book!
item.description: I am proud to announce that I‚Äôm working on a book for the Pragmatic Programmers. The title hasn‚Äôt been set in stone yet, but the book will be about programming WebAssembly with Rust.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Hoffman

item.title: How I‚Äôve found vulnerability in a popular Rust crate (and you can too)
item.description: I have recently discovered a zero-day vulnerability in a fairly popular and well-designed Rust crate. In this article I‚Äôm going to discuss how I did it and why it wasn‚Äôt discovered earlier, and introduce a new tool, libdiffuzz, that I‚Äôve created for the job. A recently discovered vulnerability in Rust standard library makes a cameo appearance.
item.dc:creator: Sergey "Shnatsel" Davidoff

item.title: Writing Rust NIFs for your Elixir code with the Rustler package
item.description: There will be times where code will run slow and Erlang/Elixir optimizations will only go so far. BEAM has several ways to interface with foreign code, the fastest way being with a Native Implemented Function (NIF) whose API expects them to be written in C. But speaking frankly, the last time I worked with C involved a lengthy debugging session that boiled down to the lack of type safety, so I‚Äôd rather not have to repeat that experience. It‚Äôs for this reason that Rust is such a compelling language.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lerche

item.title: The Undergarden, a text adventure in Rust: 1 - Sections
item.description: I‚Äôm attempting to write a (very simple, at least initally) text adventure in Rust, so I‚Äôm going to share progress on my blog starting today. This first post is about the sections, that to day is the rooms of a house for example.
item.dc:creator: Michele Beltrame

item.title: Announcing the web-sys crate!
item.description: We are pleased to announce the first release of the web-sys crate! It provides raw bindings to all the Web‚Äôs APIs: everything from DOM manipulation to WebGL to Web Audio to timers to fetch and more!
item.dc:creator: rustwasm

item.title: eBPF, ingrained in Rust
item.description: Today we are releasing RedBPF and ingraind, our eBPF toolkit that integrates with StatsD and S3, to gather feedback, and see where others in the Rust community might take this framework. If you are looking to up your company‚Äôs monitoring game, gather more data about your Raspberry Pi cluster at home, or just have a strong academic interest in Rust and low-level bit shepherding, you might want to read on.
item.dc:creator: Peter Parkanyi

item.title: ‚Äòorion‚Äô - yet another attempt at pure-Rust cryptography
item.description: orion is another attempt at cryptography implemented in pure Rust. Its main focus is usability. This is in part achieved by providing a thorough documentation of the library. High-level abstractions are also provided, which are an attempt at guiding the users towards safe usage of the lower-level functionality of the library.
item.dc:creator: brycx

item.title: Announcing Rust 1.29.1
item.description: A security vulnerability was found in the standard library where if a large number was passed to str::repeat it could cause a buffer overflow after an integer overflow. If you do not call the str::repeat function you are not affected. This has been addressed by unconditionally panicking in str::repeat on integer overflow.
item.dc:creator: The Rust Core Team

item.title: rust-on-mobile: Example of creating and running a basic "Hello World" application on iOS
item.description: This repo is a place where examples can be added of iOS/android projects written entirely/mostly in rust.
item.dc:creator: mtak-

item.title: Office Hours #1: Cyclic services
item.description: This is a report on the second ‚Äúoffice hours‚Äù, in which we discussed how to setup a series of services or actors that communicate with one another. This is a classic kind of problem in Rust: how to deal with cyclic data. Usually, the answer is that the cycle is not necessary (as in this case).
item.dc:creator: Niko Matsakis

item.title: Smithy progress update: How I decreased WebAssembly bundle size by 90%
item.description: Smithy, a web development framework written in Rust that compiles to WebAssembly. In the mean time, there has been substantial progress, and Smithy is on the verge of being ready for alpha use! In this post, I want to describe the improvements that have been made, and what‚Äôs on the Smithy roadmap!
item.dc:creator: Robert Balicki

item.title: Running Little Rust Snippets with Runner
item.description: runner is mostly a clever wrapper around normal Cargo operations. runner acts like an interpreter. There is no forced directory structure, just source. But it‚Äôs just using rustc under the hood in the most direct way possible.
item.dc:creator: Steve Donovan

item.title: Hegemon: A modular system monitor written in Rust
item.description: Hegemon is a work-in-progress modular system monitor written in safe Rust. Currently, it has the following features: Monitor CPU and memory usage, temperatures, and fan speeds; expand any data stream to reveal a more detailed graph and additional information, adjustable update interval.
item.dc:creator: Philipp Emanuel Weidmann

item.title: Office Hours #0: Debugging with GDB
item.description: This blog post is just going to be a quick summary of the basic workflow of using Rust with gdb on the command line. I‚Äôm assuming you are using Linux here, since I think otherwise you would prefer a different debugger. There are probably also nifty graphical tools you can use and maybe even IDE integrations, I‚Äôm not sure.
item.dc:creator: Niko Matsakis

item.title: Security advisory for the standard library (str::repeat)
item.description: The Rust team was recently notified of a security vulnerability affecting the standard library‚Äôs str::repeat function. When passed a large number this function has an integer overflow which can lead to an out of bounds write. If you are not using str::repeat, you are not affected.
item.dc:creator: The Rust Core Team

item.title: A Rust FFI adventure in unsafety
item.description: This blog post covers my adventure in fixing a bug in the Rust bindings for the Capstone C library, a disassembly library that supports several CPU architectures. The capstone-rs crate attempts to provide a Rusty, object-oriented interface. You do not necessarily need previous experience in C code or foreign function (FFI) bindings to understand this blog post. I will cover some of the steps I used to debug this problem. Hopefully, readers can learn from my mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Travis Finkenauer

item.title: Trying to tackle the orphans problem
item.description: In this blog entry, I want to explore a specific problem of orphans and how I decided to solve it in a crate of mine. The problem is the following: Given a crate that has a given responsibility, how can someone add an implementation of a given trait without having to use a type wrapper or augment the crate‚Äôs scope?
item.dc:creator: Dimitri Sabadie

item.title: The evolution of performance in ppbert
item.description: Today I released ppbert 0.8.4. This release also marks the first time that one of my original test files can be pretty printed in less than a second. I‚Äôll use this occasion to look back on ppbert and how I was able to improve its performance, little by little.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Foley

item.title: How we integrate Rust with C#
item.description:
Seq is a log server that's built using a few programming languages; we have a storage engine called Flare written in Rust, and a server application written in C#. Our language stack is something I've talked about previously.
Between Rust and C# we have a foreign function interface (FFI) that lets us call out to Rust code from within the .NET runtime. In this post I'd like to explore our approach to FFI between Seq and its storage engine using the API for reading log events as a reference.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Mannix

item.title: Falling in love with Rust
item.description: We are living in a Golden Age of software, one that will produce artifacts that will endure for generations. Of course, it can be hard to hold such heady thoughts when we seem to be up to our armpits in vendored flotsam, flooded by sloppy abstractions hastily implemented. Among current languages, only Rust seems to share this aspiration for permanence, with a perspective that is decidedly larger than itself.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Cantrill

item.title: Lockout, Part 2: And nary a function to be found
item.description: This is part of a blog series on working towards an intuitive mental model for lifetimes in Rust. When I tried to sit myself down and really, really write down an in-depth example‚Ä¶ I realized that there was no two ways about it. Before you can learn to appreciate why lifetimes exist, you must learn what life would be like without them. And in order to do that, well‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamparski

item.title: Announcing Linkerd 2.0: from service mesh to service sidecar
item.description: The 2.0 release of Linkerd brings two very significant changes. First, we‚Äôve completely rewritten Linkerd to be orders of magnitude faster and smaller than Linkerd 1.x. Linkerd 2.0‚Äôs data plane is comprised of ultralight Rust proxies which consume around 10mb of RSS and have a p99 latency of <1ms. Linkerd‚Äôs minimalist control plane (written in Go) is similarly designed for speed and low resource footprint.
item.dc:creator: William Morgan

item.title: Lockout, Part 1: Everything you know about lifetimes is wrong
item.description: This is part of a blog series on a new way to look at lifetimes in Rust's type system. I hope to cover some advanced aspects of lifetimes that are seldom discussed in the open, and my goal is ultimately to help convey new intuitions about how to use them correctly.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamparski

item.title: Alacritty now supports scrollback
item.description: Alacritty, the OpenGL terminal emulator written in Rust, now supports scrollback! Performance has improved, and we've got benchmarks to share.
item.dc:creator: Joe Wilm

item.title: My Experience in Increasing Rust's Reach 2018
item.description: I recently had the privilege of participating the Increasing Rust‚Äôs Reach(IRR) program. The program aims to grow Rust‚Äôs community of project collaborators and leaders. Increasing Rust‚Äôs Reach brings together Rust team members and individuals who are underrepresented in Rust‚Äôs community and the tech industry for a partnership of three (3) months, from mid-May to mid-August. Each partnership agrees to a commitment of 3‚Äì5 hours per week working on a Rust Project.
item.dc:creator: Rahul Thakoor

item.title: A Sudoku Solver & Generator üî¢
item.description: For a small side project I‚Äôm working on, I‚Äôm using a Sudoku puzzle solver and puzzle generator that I‚Äôve written in Rust. The experience was fun, so I thought I‚Äôd write up a little bit about the algorithm I‚Äôve used and some interesting stats about how it performs.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Levick

item.title: Browsing your mail with Rust and Qt
item.description: Let‚Äôs write a mail viewer with Rust and Qt. This is another blog about Rust Qt Binding Generator, the project that lets you add a Qt GUI to your Rust code, or if you will, add Rust to your Qt program.
item.dc:creator: Jos van den Oever

item.title: Ownership Explained with Python
item.description: It‚Äôs not immediately obvious that calling min(squares) modifies squares. If squares were a list or even a range, we would be able to call min and max on it with no problem. It would be nice if the language prevented us from trying to use something twice that can only be used once. Almost all modern languages, both statically and dynamically typed, will fail at runtime in these situations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kernfeld

item.title: My recommended crates for computer graphics
item.description: It‚Äôs been a while since my last post! Lately I‚Äôve been quite demotivated to actually produce something worth while for doing a writeup about. Instead I offer you some thoughts on my recent findings using rust and some crates I found particularly useful for computer graphics.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Steyfkens

item.title: Function composition in Rust using a custom smart pointer
item.description: Still drunk with the power of function composition, I started to play around with the technique in Rust, a language I've been experimenting with. Rust is a low-level language with a strict compiler that saves you from doing dangerous things. Furthermore, Rust is a functional language. It has several concepts and features inspired by Haskell (read more) and Scala for example. The design of Rust makes it highly expressive and attractive.
item.dc:creator: Bal√°zs S√∂ptei

item.title: You can't "turn off the borrow checker" in Rust
item.description: Every once in a while, someone will talk about unsafe in Rust, and how it ‚Äúturns off the borrow checker.‚Äù I think this framing leads to misconceptions about unsafe and how it interacts with safe code. Here‚Äôs some code that causes a borrow checker... | Steve Klabnik | ‚ÄúThe most violent element in society is ignorance.‚Äù - Emma Goldman
item.dc:creator: Steve Klabnik

item.title: My RustConf 2018 Closing Keynote
item.description: I said in my talk that I would post a potentially more interesting long-form version of the talk that includes things that I couldn‚Äôt fit into the 30-ish minute time slot. What I‚Äôve included below is my original long-form version of this talk, but my original intention was not to post this as-is. Originally I wanted to clean this up a bit more and make this into something that wasn‚Äôt so much a giant wall of text, but after I started doing this I realized that I was just rewriting it entirely, and at that rate I would never get around to releasing it, which I promised I would do in a timely manner.
item.dc:creator: Catherine West

item.title: TOTP generator with account handling for multiple tokens
item.description: a totp generator I wrote a while ago in C++ but now it‚Äôs in rust. It can generate a token and save it into an account file that is AES encrypted. The password is never saved, so it‚Äôs secure enough to use it. One of it‚Äôs properties it will have over the c++ implementation is it‚Äôs safe, it uses a proper IV and once I‚Äôm done, it will also support encryption via PGP.
item.dc:creator: Gergely Brautigam

item.title: Rust Associated Type
item.description: Associated Types in Rust are similar to Generic Types; however, Associated Types limit the types of things a user can do, which consequently facilitates code management. Among the Generic Types of traits, types that depend on the type of trait implementation can be expressed by using the Associated Type syntax. By comparing the Associated and Generic Types, you can get a better understanding of Associated Types.
item.dc:creator: Seung Woo Kim

item.title: Postgres over TLS with postgres and r2d2_postgres
item.description: In this post we‚Äôll go over how to get the postgres crate and r2d2_postgres working with openssl for connection pooling with TLS.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mayer's

item.title: Announcing Rust 1.29
item.description: The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.29.0. The two most significant things in this release aren‚Äôt even language features: they‚Äôre new abilities that Cargo has grown, and they‚Äôre both about lints: cargo fix can automatically fix your code that has warnings. cargo clippy is a bunch of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.
item.dc:creator: The Rust Core Team

item.title: Measuring SmallVec Footprint with Smallvectune
item.description: Rust is all about paying only for what you use, and gives us plenty tools to eliminate unneeded allocation. One of the tools that is used in a lot of crates (crates.io shows 98 dependent crates) is SmallVec. It is also used in the Rust compiler. I recently got around to speed up the operation of getting a SmallVec from a slice of copyable data. In short, they‚Äôre awesome.
item.dc:creator: Llogiq

item.title: Transparent encryption and decryption in rust with cryptostreams
item.description:
The rust community has fortunately adopted the OpenSSL bindings as the approach of choice, and the rust-openssl crate makes it easy to both bundle and consume the openssl bindings from rust in a cross-platform manner. What it doesn‚Äôt do is make encryption and decryption any easier than OpenSSL itself does.
Enter the cryptostream crate. Released on github and on crates.io under the MIT public license, cryptostream finally provides an easy and transparent way to add encryption and decryption to pipelines involving objects implementing Read or Write, making encryption (or decryption) as easy as creating a new cryptostream object, passing in an existing Read/Write impl, and then reading/writing from/to the cryptostream instead.
item.dc:creator: Mahmoud Al-Qudsi

item.title: Parallelizing PNG, part 8: Rust macros for constant specialization
item.description: In my last posts I covered profiling and some tips for optimizing inner loops in Rust code while working on a multithreaded PNG encoder. Rust‚Äôs macro system is another powerful tool for simplifying your code, and sometimes awesomeizing your performance‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Brion Vibber

item.title: Rust: Pass-By-Value or Pass-By-Reference?
item.description: The other day, a friend of mine who is learning Rust asked if Rust is a pass-by-value or a pass-by-reference language. For the unfamiliar, pass-by-value means that when passing an argument to a function it gets copied into the new function so that the value in the calling function and the value in the called function are two separate values. Changes to one will not in turn result in the same change to the other. Pass-by-reference, on the other hand, means that when passing an argument to a function, it doesn‚Äôt copy the value but rather the argument is merely a transparent reference to the original value. This means changes to the value in the called function change the value in the calling function since they are the same value.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Levick

item.title: Rust and JavaScript Interop ‚ÜîÔ∏è
item.description: In recent projects of mine, I‚Äôve been using WebAssembly quite a bit. WebAssembly (Wasm) is ‚Äúa new binary instruction format for a stack based virtual machine‚Äù that lets you use languages besides JavaScript to run code on a web page - usually either for performance reasons or to run code you‚Äôd like to share across different platforms. In my opinion, the most promising of these languages, due to its lack of a need for a runtime and great tooling is Rust.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Levick

item.title: How we organize a complex Rust codebase
item.description: At Datalust we‚Äôve been busy building Flare: a storage engine for our log server, Seq, written in the Rust programming language. This post is a point-in-time look at how we've approached building this fairly complex piece of software in Rust in 2018. I‚Äôd like to share a few
item.dc:creator: Ashley Mannix

item.title: Parallelizing PNG, part 7: Rust profiling on Linux
item.description:
I already covered some inner-loop optimization tricks for low-level Rust code in mtpng, but how do you check how fast bits of your code are anyway?
The way to go is to use a sampling-based profiler native to your operating system. I‚Äôve done most of my detailed profiling on Linux, using the ‚Äúperf‚Äù tool.
item.dc:creator: Brion Vibber

item.title: From Rust to beyond: The C galaxy
item.description: This blog post is part of a series explaining how to send Rust beyond earth, into many different galaxies. The galaxy we will explore today is the C galaxy. This post will explain what C is (shortly), how to compile any Rust program in C in theory, and how to do that practically with our Rust parser from the Rust side and the C side. We will also see how to test such a binding.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Enderlin

item.title: Rising Tide: building a modular web framework in the open
item.description: The Network Services Working Group aims to improve the story for web development this year in several respects: by bolstering foundations like async/await, by improving the ecosystem of web-related crates, and by pulling these pieces together into a framework and book called Tide. The name ‚ÄúTide‚Äù refers to ‚Äúa rising tide lifts all boats‚Äù; the intent is to improve sharing, compatibility, and improvements across all web development and frameworks in Rust.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Turon

item.title: Unit Type Params
item.description:
I always enjoy reading blogs about patterns or tricks people have picked up writing Rust. I‚Äôve seen this a few times but not read about it anywhere.
I‚Äôve been doing class assignments from Operating Systems cs140e. I highly recommend this class if you know a bit of Rust and would like to try writing some lower level code. The class involves building bits of an OS for the raspberry pi.
item.dc:creator: Evan Cameron

item.title: GStreamer Rust bindings 0.12 and GStreamer Plugin 0.3 release
item.description: After almost 6 months, a new release of the GStreamer Rust bindings and the GStreamer plugin writing infrastructure for Rust is out. As usual this was coinciding with the release of all the gtk-rs crates to make use of all the new features they contain.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Dr√∂ge

item.title: Parallelizing PNG: Choosing Rust for mtpng
item.description: In my last post I wrapped up the patches to improve perceived performance of screenshots on the Linux GNOME desktop. With that done, why not implement my crazy plan for parallel PNG encoding to speed the actual save time?
item.dc:creator: Brion Vibber

item.title: Sonnerie: A simple timeseries database
item.description: Sonnerie is a time-series database. Map a timestamp to a floating-point value. Store multiple of these series in a single database. Insert tens of millions of samples in minutes, on rotational media.
item.dc:creator: Kalle Samuels

item.title: The Common Rust Traits
item.description:
In Rust, data types - primitives, structs, enums and any other ‚Äòaggregate‚Äô types like tuples and arrays - are dumb. They may have methods but that is just a convenience (they are just functions). Types have no relationship with each other.
Traits are the abstract mechanism for adding functionality to types and establishing relationships between them.
item.dc:creator: Steve Donovan

item.title: Tower Web ‚Äî Expanding the middleware stack
item.description: tower-web version 0.2.2 has been released. It comes with a number of new features, which I will talk about in this post. Primarily, the middleware story is starting to come together. I will be expanding some on how middleware fits into Tower and web in general.
item.dc:creator: Carl Lerche

item.title: Rust: My first impressions
item.description:
At work I‚Äôm seeing more and more embedded software; over the past few years in, among others, coffee machines, forklifts, and cars. Embedded software needs to be fast and extremely efficient with hardware resources. In some cases it not even acceptable to have a tiny break for some garbage collection. So, typical tech stacks for backend development can‚Äôt be used, never mind anything that uses browser technologies. Unsurprisingly, almost all embedded software is written in C++, and, in fact, that is also what I used recently for a personal project with a micro-controller.
Looking through the remaining choices, I went past Golang, which uses garbage collection, and set my eyes on Rust. In this post I‚Äôll describe my first impressions, some of the frustrating moments, but also the extremely impressive performance on a larger piece of code.
item.dc:creator: Erik D√∂rnenburg

item.title: Rust Faster SIMD edition
item.description: It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been playing the benchmarksgame with Rust. But I recently found an interesting crate called packed_simd which had a SIMD-ified version of some benchmarks, so as Rust stable now has stdsimd, we should be able to speed up our benchmarks quite a bit.
item.dc:creator: Llogiq

item.title: Beware the rust cache on Travis
item.description: Today, I was working on optimizing my travis builds to speed them up, especially in the direction of caching. Travis allows you to set cache: cargo in your .travis.yml to enable caching for rust projects and caching is cool: it avoids having to rebuild all dependencies all the time, speeding up the builds. Or does it?
item.dc:creator: Victor "Levans" Berger

item.title: Beware the rust cache on Travis
item.description: Today, I was working on optimizing my travis builds to speed them up, especially in the direction of caching. Travis allows you to set cache: cargo in your .travis.yml to enable caching for rust projects and caching is cool: it avoids having to rebuild all dependencies all the time, speeding up the builds.
item.dc:creator: Victor "Levans" Berger

item.title: Adventures in Rust: Futures and Tokio
item.description:
One of my newer hobbies recently has been learning and toying around with Rust. Recently, as part of this learning process, I've started implementing an IP address lookup service as a small side project. During the course of implementing this project I ran into what turned out to be a bit of a hurdle to tackle, specifically performing reverse dns resolution asynchronously.
My hope is that through exploring this problem, I can aid others in understanding these concepts which can be initially difficult grasp. This is especially so as the behavior and function of Futures vary wildly between various languages and runtimes.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Gilbert

item.title: Rust at Datalust
item.description: At Datalust we build a log server called Seq. It's really a database, written in C#, with its own SQL-based query language, that's specifically designed for storing and querying structured log data. In the past, Seq has managed log event storage through ESENT, which is a storage technology baked into Windows. For our cross-platform Seq 5 release we‚Äôve built a storage engine called Flare in the Rust programming language to replace our usage of ESENT.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Mannix

item.title: Announcing Spirit
item.description: Spirit is a crate that cuts down on boilerplate when creating unix daemons, with support for live configuration reloading.
item.dc:creator: Michal 'vorner' Vaner

item.title: RPCS3 and Dolphin emulators on macOS using gfx-portability
item.description: After improving functionality and performance of gfx-portability‚Äôs Metal backend through benchmarking Dota2, and verifying certain functionality through the Vulkan Conformance Test Suite (CTS), we decided to expand our testing to other projects. We quickly found two projects which matched our criteria: RPCS3 and Dolphin.
item.dc:creator: gfx-rs

item.title: Time difference between L1 cache fetch and memory fetch
item.description: Aim: Measure how fast a fetch from L1 cache is when compared to a fetch from memory. Instead of writing pure assembly code, we will use Rust's inline assembly feature.
item.dc:creator: Nitish Chinta

item.title: Programming Servo: A generic ‚Äúworker event-loop‚Äù
item.description: Let‚Äôs take a look at how in Rust you can have an algorithm generic over T, where T is further bound by a trait, which itself is generic over one of several parameters.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Terzian

item.title: Rust pattern: Iterating an over a Rc<Vec<T>>
item.description: This post examines a particular, seemingly simple problem: given ownership of a Rc<Vec<u32>>, can we write a function that returns an impl Iterator<Item = u32>? It turns out that this is a bit harder than it might at first appear ‚Äì and, as we‚Äôll see, for good reason. I‚Äôll dig into what‚Äôs going on, how you can fix it, and how we might extend the language in the future to try and get past this challenge.
item.dc:creator: Niko Matsakis

item.title: Rust Factory Without Box (Trait Object)
item.description: I‚Äôve been playing around a lot with Rust recently and it‚Äôs quickly becoming my second-favourite programming language. One of the things I‚Äôve been playing with is some Object Oriented design concepts as they might apply.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Paul Weber

item.title: Using RwLock and CondVars in Rust
item.description:
Read many, write exclusive locks ‚Äì RwLock Consider a situation where you have a resource that must be manipulated only a single thread at a time, but is safe to be queried by many‚Äîthat is, you have many readers and only one writer.
While you could protect this resource with a mutex, the trouble is that the mutex makes no distinction between its lockers; every thread will be forced to wait, no matter what their intentions.
item.dc:creator: Brian L. Troutwine

item.title: Primitives in Rust are Weird (and Cool)
item.description: I wrote a really small Rust program a while back because I was curious. I was 100% convinced itcouldn‚Äôt possibly run. And to my complete befuddlement, it compiled, ran, and produced a completely sensible output.
item.dc:creator: Bradlee Speice

item.title: GIR support in gnome-class
item.description: Recently I've been working again in the rust port of libgepub, libgepub is C code, but in the rust-migration branch almost all the real functionality is done with rust and the GepubDoc class is a GObject wrapper around that code. For this reason I was thinking about to use gnome-class to implement GepubDoc. Gnome-class is a rust lib to write GObject code in rust that's compatible with the C binary API so then you can call this new GObject code written with gnome-class from C. So, libgepub is the excuse to start to implement GIR in gnome-class.
item.dc:creator: danigm

item.title: O(1) sum_of_multiples() in Rust
item.description: I had been working mostly in Scala for a while, then took a diversion into Swift and Objective C. I wanted to learn another language after that, and had all but decided on Clojure. But Rust kept nagging at me ‚Äî there was something about it. So I watched some videos, then read the book, and then started the Rust track at Exercism.io.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Sterling

item.title: Rust: Fail Fast and Loudly
item.description: To panic or to return a Result: why libraries in Rust must weigh their options rather than accepting a never-panic mandate.
item.dc:creator: Shivoa Birch

item.title: Benchmarking a Rust web application
item.description:
I set out out my goal 9 for Rustnish: Write benchmark code that compares runtime performance of Rustnish against Varnish. Use cargo bench to execute the benchmarks.
The basic idea of a performance test here is to send many HTTP requests to the web service (the reverse proxy in this case) and measure how fast the responses arrive back. Comparing the results from Rustnish and Varnish should give us an idea if our performance expectations are holding up.
item.dc:creator: klausi

item.title: Introduction to asynchronous programming in Rust
item.description: An alternate introdcution to the APR book. This book aims to be a comprehensive, up-to-date guide on the async story in Rust, appropriate for beginners and old hands alike. We assume you already know Rust fairly well, including having done some multi-threaded programming. If any Rust terms in this guide are unfamiliar, you should check out the Rust book.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cameron

item.title: Debugging an Rc<T> reference leak in Rust
item.description: The bug that caused two brown-paper-bag releases in librsvg ‚Äî because it was leaking all the SVG nodes ‚Äî has been interesting. Memory leaks in Rust? Isn't it supposed to prevent that? Well, yeah, but the leaks were caused by the C side of things, and by unsafe code in Rust, which does not prevent leaks.
item.dc:creator: Federico Mena Quintero

item.title: Feasible functors in Rust
item.description: withoutboats, one of the Rust language design team, recently posted a thread on the infeasibility of monads as a useful abstraction technique in Rust, as a response to the persistence of some (usually from outside the Rust community) in claiming that ‚ÄúRust is doing things incorrectly‚Äù by developing specific solutions to problems, rather than using a general category theoretic framework for everything. The points demonstrate real difficulties with attempting to use a general framework for these problems and to me serves perfectly as a ‚Äúthe ball‚Äôs in your court now‚Äù to anyone claiming Rust is ignoring theory and coming up with unnecessary solutions to solved problems: if you think Rust could use monadic abstractions, you have to be able to address these counterarguments.
item.dc:creator: varkor

item.title: Programming Servo: the makings of a task-queue
item.description: In Servo, task-sources are implemented via a channel, whose sender is cloned for each specific task-source, and where tasks are messages sent on the channel and containing a closure representing the actual task.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Terzian

item.title: From Rust to beyond: The ASM.js galaxy
item.description: The second galaxy that our Rust parser will explore is the ASM.js galaxy. This post will explain what ASM.js is, how to compile the parser into ASM.js, and how to use the ASM.js module with Javascript in a browser. The goal is to use ASM.js as a fallback to WebAssembly when it is not available. I highly recommend to read the previous episode about WebAssembly since they have a lot in common.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Enderlin

item.title: Serde Deserialize This or That into u64
item.description: Recently I ran into a bug in my code; hey, it happens. The bug was that I had a struct which could serialize into json, but could not deserialize from its own json. The struct holds a value for a mac address, which is 48-bit integer (that i store in a u64), but it is serialized using the network interface name. For example on my mac, i have a network interface named en1 with the mac address of 20:c9:d0:b0:a4:71.
item.dc:creator: Noyez

item.title: Oxidizing sourmash: WebAssembly
item.description: In "Oxidizing sourmash: Python and FFI" I described my road to learn Rust, but something that I omitted was that around the same time the WebAssembly support in Rust started to look better and better and was a huge influence in my decision to learn Rust. Reimplementing the sourmash C++ extension in Rust and use the same codebase in the browser sounded very attractive, and now that it was working I started looking into how to use the WebAssembly target in Rust.
item.dc:creator: Luiz Irber

item.title: Thoughts on Rust from a PHP developer!
item.description: I first starting learning Rust about 6 months ago, I was looking for a new language to learn when I came across it. At first I thought Rust was only meant to be a low level, systems programming language, but the more I learned, the more I realised the potential it has for high level programming and web applications. Also, along the way I learned many ways in which Rust prevents many of the typical bugs often found in applications written in other programming languages.
item.dc:creator: Diego Cabrejas
